s.text: The conventional way to read your favorite Internet content is to dial up to the Internet, find your favorite site(s), wait for them to download, navigate to items of interest, wait for them to download, and so forth.
The advantage to you is that it's all there waiting to be read, at fast hard-drive speed instead of slow modem speed.
To read two weeks of cartoons, I would have to click on each cartoon's date and wait for that image to download.

The conventional way to read your favorite Internet content is to dial up to the Internet, find your favorite site(s), wait for them to download, navigate to items of interest, wait for them to download, and so forth.

The first generation of these, such as WebWhacker, Milktruck (now WebEx), and FreeLoader, all work pretty much the same way: You tell the software which sites you want downloaded, and the software tells your computer to do it at prearranged times.
But PointCast's success at "push" is drawing lots of rivals, both small start-ups and the big boys.
But PointCast's success at "push" is drawing lots of rivals, both small start-ups and the big boys.
PointCast has succeeded so far with a mass-market approach--relatively few news sources, sorted into relatively few "buckets."
PointCast has succeeded so far with a mass-market approach--relatively few news sources, sorted into relatively few "buckets."
Microsoft's Internet Explorer 4.0 will provide an "Active Desktop," which shows "pushed" content right there behind your Windows windows.
"Push" refers to the way that information gets delivered.
"Push" refers to the way that information gets delivered.
That's why some sites (like Slate) sport FreeLoader logos, while others (like the Wall Street Journal) might recommend WebEx.
The advantage to the information provider is that information "pushed" at customers is more likely to find them than information they must go out and "pull."
When I go back, I find that it has already downloaded the last two weeks' cartoons, making my experience fast and easy.
That helps to explain PointCast's popularity: The company claims that 1.7 million users have downloaded its software to date, and that its site gets 40 million hits a day.
To read two weeks of cartoons, I would have to click on each cartoon's date and wait for that image to download.
